manual_description: Israel is a one-of-a-kind destination. Adventurers can enjoy the Dead Sea, hike the Golan Heights, and explore the desert on a camel ride. History buffs will marvel at the ancient landmarks and their significance to Judaism, Christianity, and Islam. Art lovers will appreciate the museums, galleries, and architecture. Spend time in the ancient lands of the Bible, in a cosmopolitan city like Tel Aviv, or in the Red Sea resort of Eilat.
place_description: Israel, officially the State of Israel, is a country in the Southern Levant region of West Asia. It is bordered by Lebanon and Syria to the north, the West Bank and Jordan to the east, the Gaza Strip and Egypt to the southwest, and the Mediterranean Sea to the west. Wikipedia.

top_attractions.detail_description:
These formal gardens flowing down 19 steep terraces to a resplendent domed shrine – the final resting place of the prophet-herald of the Baha’i faith – are Haifa’s crowning attraction. There are bird’s-eye views from the platform at the top, but we highly recommend the free, 45-minute Panorama Tour. Tours begin daily (except Wednesday) at 11.30am in Hebrew and noon in English. Arrive half an hour ahead as it's first come, first served. Men and women must be covered from shoulders to knees.
The gardens are tended by the Baha’i World Centre, the religion’s global headquarters. Emerald lawns and bright flower beds ripple down to the Shrine of the Báb, which is even more dazzling against a backdrop of deep blue Haifa Bay. Completed in 1953, this glinting dome guards the mortal remains of the Báb, the spiritual predecessor to the Baha’i faith’s main prophet Baha’ullah. After persecution and imprisonment, the Báb was executed in Persia in 1850 and his remains were secretly kept by his followers. They were brought to Haifa in 1909 and Baha’ullah chose this spot for the Báb’s burial place. Combining the style and proportions of European architecture with motifs inspired by Eastern traditions, it was designed by a Canadian architect, built with Italian stone and decorated with Portuguese fire-glazed tiles.Framing the shrine, the gardens were laid out on the slopes of Mt Carmel between 1989 and 2001. They were given Unesco World Heritage status in 2008 along with Akko’s Shrine of Baha’ullah. Impressively symmetrical, the well-tended terraces have a regal feel: gurgling fountains, flower beds, stone eagles, hedges trimmed into eight-pointed stars, and lawns with barely a blade of grass out of place. (Suddenly, the stringent rules of conduct – no food, no smoking, no setting foot on the lawns – make a whole lot of sense.) The gardens are illuminated throughout the night, a spiritual solace for the Báb’s years of imprisonment in near-darkness; you can enjoy this sparkling view from the German Colony.Buildings (closed to the public) around the gardens include the Universal House of Justice, a domed neoclassical structure with Corinthian columns from which the Baha’is’ spiritual and administrative affairs are governed; and the Archives, in a green-roofed structure that looks like the Parthenon, in which are kept more than 100 different translations of the Kitáb-i-Aqdas, the holy book of the Baha’i faith.To get to the start of the Panorama Tour from Carmel Centre (the Carmelit’s Gan HaEm stop), walk 1km north along Yefe Nof St, which affords the city’s finest bay views. Alternatively, from Bat Galim Egged bus 136 zigzags via Ben Gurion Blvd up to HaNassi Ave (parallel to Yefe Nof). The tour finishes down on HaTziyonut Blvd – to get back up to Carmel Centre, there is usually a sherut (10NIS) waiting; count on paying about 30NIS for a taxi. Bus 115 links the lower entrance on HaTziyonut Blvd with Haifa-Hof HaCarmel bus station and Talpiot market.Note that the line for the Panorama Tour can be long when there’s a cruise liner or US Navy ship in port. Admission is limited to 60 people (120 if there are two guides available). See the website for a monthly schedule of less regular tours in Russian and Arabic.

seasonal.Regional Highlights – Tel Aviv: Known for its modern architecture, vibrant nightlife, and beautiful beaches, Tel Aviv is a hub of culture and innovation.
seasonal.Regional Highlights – Jerusalem: A city of profound historical and religious significance, home to the Western Wall, the Dome of the Rock, and the Church of the Holy Sepulchre.
seasonal.March to May: Spring in Israel is characterized by blooming flowers and pleasant weather, making it one of the best times to visit. Temperatures are comfortable, ranging from mild to warm, perfect for outdoor activities and exploring national parks. This season also hosts various cultural festivals, including Passover, which offers a unique insight into Jewish traditions. Popular destinations include the Sea of Galilee and the Negev Desert.
seasonal.June to August: Summer in Israel can be hot, especially in the southern regions, with temperatures often exceeding 30°C (86°F). Coastal cities like Tel Aviv and Haifa are popular for their beaches and vibrant nightlife. Visitors can enjoy water sports, beach parties, and outdoor festivals. However, it's essential to stay hydrated and seek shade during the hottest parts of the day. This is also a peak tourist season, so expect larger crowds at major attractions.
seasonal.Travel Tip: When visiting Israel, it's important to respect local customs and traditions, especially in religious sites. Dress modestly when visiting places of worship, and be mindful of cultural sensitivities. Additionally, consider using public transportation or walking to explore cities, as traffic can be congested. Always stay hydrated, especially during the hot summer months.
seasonal.Regional Highlights – Nazareth: The childhood home of Jesus, Nazareth is rich in Christian history and features significant religious sites.
seasonal.Regional Highlights – Eilat: A resort city on the Red Sea, Eilat is known for its coral reefs, water sports, and warm climate year-round.
seasonal.Regional Highlights – Haifa: Famous for the Baha'i Gardens and its picturesque port, Haifa offers a blend of cultures and stunning views of the Mediterranean.
seasonal.Overview: Israel is a small yet diverse country located in the Middle East, known for its rich history, cultural heritage, and stunning landscapes. From the bustling streets of Jerusalem to the vibrant beaches of Tel Aviv, Israel offers a unique blend of ancient traditions and modern attractions. Visitors can explore historical sites, enjoy delicious cuisine, and experience a variety of outdoor activities.
seasonal.December to February: During the winter months, Israel experiences mild temperatures, making it a great time for sightseeing. Jerusalem can be chilly, especially at night, while Tel Aviv enjoys a more temperate climate. This season is ideal for visiting historical sites without the crowds, and travelers can enjoy festive events, including Hanukkah celebrations. Rain is possible, so packing a light jacket and umbrella is advisable.
seasonal.September to November: Fall brings cooler temperatures and is considered another excellent time to visit Israel. The weather is pleasant, making it ideal for hiking and exploring historical sites. The Jewish High Holidays, including Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur, occur during this period, offering a unique cultural experience. The landscapes are particularly beautiful as the leaves change color, especially in the Galilee region.

travelInfo.🌞 Weather Considerations: Israel has a Mediterranean climate, with hot summers and mild winters. Be sure to check the weather forecast and pack accordingly, especially if you plan to visit during the summer months.
travelInfo.👗 Cultural Dress Codes: While Israel is generally liberal, it's respectful to dress modestly when visiting religious sites. Women should cover their shoulders and knees, and men should avoid wearing shorts in these areas.
travelInfo.Conclusion: Israel offers a rich tapestry of experiences for every traveler. Embrace the adventure and immerse yourself in the beauty and diversity of this remarkable country.
travelInfo.🍽️ Local Cuisine: Don't miss out on trying traditional Israeli dishes such as falafel, hummus, and shakshuka. Exploring local markets and street food stalls can provide a delicious and authentic culinary experience.
travelInfo.Introduction: Visiting Israel is a unique experience that blends rich history, diverse cultures, and stunning landscapes. Whether you're exploring ancient sites or enjoying modern cities, there are a few essential tips to keep in mind for a smooth journey.
travelInfo.🚗 Transportation Tips: Public transportation in Israel is efficient, with buses and trains connecting major cities. Consider purchasing a Rav Kav card for easy access to public transit and to save on fares.
travelInfo.🕌 Must-See Historical Sites: Israel is home to numerous historical landmarks, including the Western Wall, Masada, and the ancient city of Jerusalem. Plan your itinerary to include these iconic sites for a deeper understanding of the region's history.
travelInfo.💰 Currency and Costs: The local currency is the Israeli Shekel (ILS). Be prepared for varying costs, as some areas can be quite expensive, while others offer budget-friendly options.
travelInfo.📅 Best Times to Visit: The best times to visit Israel are during the spring (March to May) and fall (September to November) when the weather is pleasant. Avoid major holidays if you prefer fewer crowds.
travelInfo.🕊️ Understanding Local Customs: Israelis are known for their directness and hospitality. Embrace the local culture by being open and friendly, and don't hesitate to engage in conversations with locals.

travelInfo.Conclusion: Navigating visa requirements for Israel can seem daunting, but with the right information, the process can be straightforward. Ensure you understand the requirements and prepare your application carefully for a successful trip.
travelInfo.🛬 Tourist Visas: Tourist visas are available for travelers planning to visit Israel for leisure. Most tourists from certain countries can enter Israel without a visa for short stays, while others may need to apply in advance.
travelInfo.🔍 Common Mistakes to Avoid: Many applicants make common mistakes that can delay or jeopardize their visa applications. It's crucial to double-check all forms, ensure documents are complete, and adhere to submission guidelines to avoid issues.
travelInfo.🛂 Visa Categories & Eligibility: Israel offers various visa categories, including tourist, business, and student visas. Each category has specific eligibility requirements that applicants must meet to obtain the appropriate visa for their visit.
travelInfo.Introduction: Understanding visa requirements for Israel is essential for travelers planning to visit this vibrant country. This guide provides comprehensive information on the types of visas available, eligibility criteria, and the application process to ensure a smooth journey.
travelInfo.🌐 Application Process: The application process for an Israeli visa can vary depending on the type of visa and the applicant's nationality. Generally, it involves submitting an application form, supporting documents, and sometimes attending an interview at an Israeli consulate or embassy.
travelInfo.📅 Visa Validity & Extensions: Visa validity periods vary based on the type of visa issued. In some cases, it is possible to extend a visa while in Israel, but this requires submitting a request to the relevant authorities before the current visa expires.
travelInfo.🏫 Student Visas: International students wishing to study in Israel must apply for a student visa. This visa is granted to individuals accepted into recognized educational institutions and allows them to reside in Israel for the duration of their studies.
travelInfo.🗺️ Entry Restrictions & Regulations: Travelers should be aware of any entry restrictions or regulations that may be in place, especially in light of health and safety protocols. Staying informed about the latest travel advisories is essential for a hassle-free entry into Israel.
travelInfo.💼 Business Visas: For those traveling to Israel for business purposes, a business visa is required. This visa allows foreign nationals to attend meetings, conferences, and other business-related activities while in the country.
travelInfo.📄 Required Documents: When applying for an Israeli visa, applicants must provide various documents, including a valid passport, photographs, proof of accommodation, and financial means. Additional documents may be required based on the visa type.

travelInfo.🚇 Light Rail: Cities like Jerusalem and Tel Aviv have light rail systems that offer efficient transport within the city. These modern trams are a great way to avoid traffic and explore local attractions.
travelInfo.🚕 Taxis: Taxis are readily available in cities and can be hailed on the street or booked via apps. They provide a quick and convenient way to navigate urban areas, especially when traveling with luggage.
travelInfo.🚌 Buses: The bus network in Israel is extensive and affordable, covering both urban and rural areas. Buses are a great way to reach destinations that may not be accessible by train.
travelInfo.Conclusion: With a variety of transportation options available, getting around in Israel can be both easy and enjoyable. Embrace the journey and make the most of your travel experience!
travelInfo.🚙 Car Rentals: Renting a car gives you the freedom to explore Israel at your own pace, especially in more remote areas. Be sure to familiarize yourself with local driving laws and parking regulations.
travelInfo.Introduction: Getting around in Israel can be an exciting adventure, offering a variety of transportation options to explore the country's rich history and vibrant culture. From bustling cities to serene landscapes, understanding the available modes of transport will enhance your travel experience.
travelInfo.🛳 Ferries: Ferries operate in certain coastal areas, such as Haifa and Tel Aviv, offering a unique way to travel while enjoying beautiful sea views. They can be a relaxing alternative to road travel.
travelInfo.🚶 Walking: Walking is often the best way to experience the charm of Israeli cities. Many urban areas are pedestrian-friendly, allowing you to discover hidden gems and local culture up close.
travelInfo.🛴 Scooters: Electric scooters are available for rent in many cities, providing a quick and eco-friendly way to get around. They are perfect for short distances and can be easily found through various apps.
travelInfo.🚲 Bicycles: Cycling is becoming increasingly popular in Israel, with many cities offering bike-sharing programs and dedicated lanes. Renting a bike is a fun way to explore urban areas at your own pace.
travelInfo.🚄 Trains: Israel's train system connects major cities and regions, making it a convenient option for travelers. The trains are modern, comfortable, and offer scenic views of the countryside.

what_to_eat.short_description: Savory pastries filled with cheese, potatoes, or spinach, bourekas boast flaky, golden-brown layers that delight the palate. A beloved snack in Israel, they blend tradition with irresistible flavor.
what_to_eat.name: Bourekas

what_to_eat.short_description: Enriched with eggs and a hint of sweetness, this traditional Jewish bread features a braided shape and a golden crust, often topped with sesame or poppy seeds for added crunch. Perfect for celebrations and Shabbat dinners, it embodies the warmth of community and heritage.
what_to_eat.name: Challah

what_to_eat.short_description: Slow-cooked to perfection, this hearty Ashkenazi Jewish stew melds tender beef, savory beans, earthy barley, and root vegetables, creating a rich, comforting dish cherished during the Sabbath.
what_to_eat.name: Cholent

what_to_eat.short_description: Crispy on the outside and tender within, these golden chickpea balls burst with the flavors of garlic, onion, and fresh herbs. A beloved staple of Israeli street food, falafel offers a tasty bite of Middle Eastern culture.
what_to_eat.name: Falafel

what_to_eat.short_description: Delight in the sweet, three-cornered Hamantash, a traditional Jewish pastry filled with poppy seeds, fruit preserves, or chocolate. Celebrated during Purim, each bite offers a rich blend of flavors and festive cheer.
what_to_eat.name: Hamantash

what_to_eat.short_description: Creamy and velvety, this Middle Eastern staple blends chickpeas, tahini, garlic, and cumin with a zesty hint of lemon. Perfect for dipping or spreading, it’s a flavorful celebration of tradition.
what_to_eat.name: Hummus

what_to_eat.short_description: Savor the vibrant flavors of an Israeli breakfast, featuring creamy labneh, fresh tomatoes, cucumbers, and perfectly cooked eggs. A delightful morning tradition that celebrates communal dining and fresh ingredients.
what_to_eat.name: Israeli breakfast

what_to_eat.short_description: Finely chopped and vibrant, this refreshing salad bursts with the flavors of ripe tomatoes, crisp cucumbers, and zesty onions. A staple in Israeli cuisine, it brings a taste of the Mediterranean to every meal.
what_to_eat.name: Israeli salad (Salat katzutz)

what_to_eat.short_description: Savor the vibrant flavors of Jerusalem with this street food classic, where succulent chicken livers, hearts, and tender pieces of chicken mingle with aromatic cumin and onions, all grilled to perfection. A true taste of local culture!
what_to_eat.name: Jerusalem mixed grill (Me'orav Yerushalmi)

what_to_eat.short_description: Originating from Eastern Europe, these savory dumplings are filled with tender meat and seasoned spices, often served in rich broth. Perfectly comforting, kreplach are a beloved Jewish tradition.
what_to_eat.name: Kreplach

what_to_eat.short_description: Originating from Ashkenazi Jewish cuisine, kugel is a comforting baked casserole of noodles or potatoes, blended with eggs and rich flavors. Its savory and sweet variations delight the senses in every bite.
what_to_eat.name: Kugel

what_to_eat.short_description: Layers of crispy kataifi dough cradle a rich, creamy Akkawi cheese filling, infused with orange zest and cardamom, all drizzled with sweet syrup. A beloved Middle Eastern dessert, kunāfah delights with its irresistible crunch and indulgent flavors.
what_to_eat.name: Kunāfah

what_to_eat.short_description: Delicate and creamy, this milk-based pudding hails from the Middle East, combining subtle sweetness with hints of rosewater and a sprinkle of pistachios for a fragrant finish.
what_to_eat.name: Malabi

what_to_eat.short_description: Laminated and flaky, this Yemenite Jewish flatbread delights with its rich layers of butter and oil. Enjoy it warm, often served with honey or savory dips for a satisfying crunch.
what_to_eat.name: Malawach

what_to_eat.short_description: Originating from Ashkenazi Jewish cuisine, Mandelbrot delights with its crisp texture and nutty almond flavor. Twice-baked to perfection, it’s a flavorful treat perfect for any occasion.
what_to_eat.name: Mandelbrot

what_to_eat.short_description: Unleavened and crisp, this traditional Israeli flatbread is crafted from just flour and water, embodying the essence of Passover. Its simple flavor makes it a versatile companion to any meal.
what_to_eat.name: Matzah

what_to_eat.short_description: Delight in these flaky, cream cheese-based pastries filled with sweet jam, nuts, or chocolate. A beloved treat from Ashkenazi Jewish roots, rugelach brings a taste of tradition to every bite.
what_to_eat.name: Rugelach

what_to_eat.short_description: Originating from Iraqi Jewish tradition, this vibrant sandwich layers crispy fried eggplant, creamy hummus, and savory hard-boiled eggs in warm pita. Topped with tangy amba and fresh salad, it’s a flavor-packed bite of Israeli street food bliss.
what_to_eat.name: Sabich

what_to_eat.short_description: Poached eggs nestle in a vibrant, spiced tomato and bell pepper sauce, infused with cumin. Originating from North Africa, this Israeli breakfast staple bursts with flavor and warmth.
what_to_eat.name: Shakshouka

what_to_eat.short_description: Marinated and spit-roasted, tender lamb, beef, or chicken is wrapped in warm pita or lavash, creating a flavorful bite steeped in rich Ottoman heritage. Perfectly spiced and utterly irresistible!
what_to_eat.name: Shawarma

what_to_eat.short_description: Round and golden, these deep-fried doughnuts burst with sweet jam, embodying the festive spirit of Hanukkah in Israel. A delightful treat that’s crispy outside and soft inside, perfect for indulgence!
what_to_eat.name: Sufganiyah

what_to_eat.short_description: Originating in Israel, this creamy dip blends toasted sesame seeds with zesty lemon juice, garlic, and a drizzle of olive oil. Its nutty flavor and smooth texture make it an irresistible accompaniment to fresh veggies or pita.
what_to_eat.name: Tahini

what_to_eat.short_description: Nutty and buttery, these Israeli treats blend rich tahini with a hint of sweetness, creating a melt-in-your-mouth delight. Perfectly baked, they showcase the beloved flavors of the Eastern Mediterranean.
what_to_eat.name: Tahini cookie (Oogiyot tahina)

what_to_eat.short_description: Broken matzah soaks in water and mingles with beaten eggs, creating a satisfying, savory treat. Traditionally enjoyed during Passover, this Ashkenazi favorite is pan-fried to golden perfection.
what_to_eat.name: מצה בריי‎‎ (Matzah brei)
